FacilityName: Flint Hills Resources Pine Bend, LLC
ParentCompanyName: Flint Hills Resources Pine Bend, LLC
OperatorName: Flint Hills Resources Pine Bend LLC

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP Executive Summary: 



This Executive Summary briefly reviews the major elements of the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Flint Hills Resources Pine Bend, LLC (FHR) Junction City, Wisconsin facility (Facility). This summary is presented in response to the requirements of the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) under 40 CFR Part 68 and 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. The Junction City facility is subject to the RMP rule due to the storage of propane above the threshold quantity.



1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies 

Flint Hills Resources is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public.  FHR management has adopted and implemented policies that adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety is the number one consideration in the handling of propane; our goal is to prevent accidental releases through the proper design, installation, operation and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel.  The Facility is operated consistent with National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) requirements for propane facilities.



In the event that a release does occur, the Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP) is available in hard copy format at the terminal.  The ERAP is also available as part of the electronic Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) for the Junction City terminal which has been distributed to local emergency responders and is available to all terminal employees.

 

2.    Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled

The Junction City facility operates as a bulk fuel distribution and storage terminal.  The propane terminal distributes propane to wholesale customers.  Propane is received directly from a 6 inch pipeline, stored in product vessels and distributed to customers via bulk tanker trucks at the propane loading rack.  Propane is the only RMP regulated substance that the F

acility handles above the threshold quantity.  Ethyl mercaptan, a RMP regulated substance, is used to stench propane gas at the Facility, but the quantity stored is below regulatory threshold quantities.    



Access to the Facility is restricted by a card operated gate. Customers possessing access cards may load trucks 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The terminal is manned 10 hours a day Monday through Friday. 



The Facility has one (1) truck loading island for propane that is served by two (2) centrifugal type loading pumps capable of loading two (2) trucks at a time. Atmospheric vent piping is connected to a common header leading to a vent stack located to the northeast of the propane facility.



Propane is stored at the Facility in eight (8) 84,000 gallon storage vessels (bullets) for a total storage capacity of approximately 672,000 gallons.  The actual storage capacity is 85% of the water capacity, or 571,200 gallons, to allow for product expansion within the storage vessels.  The Facility utilizes a molecular sieve filter system to scrub propane received from the pipeline.



The Facility also operates two 500 gallon propane tanks which are excluded from the RMP program provisions due to their use as a fuel (40 CFR 68.126).  One of the propane tanks is used for office building heating and the second tank is used in the facilityA?s vapor combustion unit.



3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

FHR has programs in place to address accidental release prevention measures required by the EPA, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard, and all notification requirements of EPA's Emergency Response and Community Right-to-Know regulations.  The Facility complies with both RMP and PSM for the management of propane.  



Employee Participation

FHR encourages employees to participate in safety management and accident prevention. The Facility has developed an employee p

articipation program as part of the PSM program. The controlled copy of the Employee Participation Plan is available at the terminal.  All Process Safety Information, Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) results, recommendations, and action items, incident investigations, compliance audits, operating procedures, emergency response plan, and records of management of change are available to the operating personnel at any time.  



Process Hazard Analysis and Process Safety Information

An initial process hazard analysis (PHA) was completed for the Junction City propane system in February of 1993.  The PHA is revalidated at least every five years.  The controlled copy of the PHA is maintained at the terminal and details the study methodology used, items reviewed during the study (i.e., hazards of the process, facility sitting, etc.), study team composition requirements, and the system used to address study findings and recommendations. 



The Hazards and Operability (HAZOP) review technique was the primary tool used to conduct hazard evaluation studies of the propane storage and loading facilities. The HAZOP technique is a systematic method for identifying all the ways that process equipment can malfunction or be improperly operated, leading to hazardous conditions. To apply the HAZOP technique, the unit is divided into logical process sections (major vessels, pumps, interconnecting process piping, etc.). For each process section, the PHA team (1) determines if any significant safety consequences would result from the credible deviations, (2) identifies potential causes of significant safety consequences, (3) lists the engineered and administrative safeguards protecting against particular deviations, and (4) suggests actions that might reduce the likelihood or severity of the deviations.



The Facility maintains documents describing process safety information for the propane system, including material safety data sheets.



Operating Procedures and Training

Junction City

Terminal Management is responsible for developing and implementing written -operating procedures that provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities involved in each covered process consistent with the Process Safety Information. The operating procedures that have been developed have been prepared as a guide for those involved with the initial start up, normal operation, normal shutdown and emergency shutdown of the propane system. The Facility has developed and implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in facility operations.  



Contractors

Prior to all awarded contracts, the FHR representative evaluates the prior safety performance of any prospective contractor. After the contractor has been selected, the FHR representative shall conduct a contractor orientation meeting with the contract employer representative. At that time, FHR reviews with the contract employer representative all known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards which are related to the contractor's work and the terminal process. The contract employer representative is also informed of the applicable provisions of the terminal's emergency action plan, as well as conditions regarding entrance and the safe work practices to which the Contractor will have to abide in order to be allowed to work at the site. Because contractors may work on or near the process equipment, the Facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors perform their work in a safe manner, have the appropriate knowledge and skills, and are aware of the hazards in their workplace.



Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

As part of the MOC process, whenever a modification to the existing chemical process is planned, either temporary or permanent, a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) is required.  The PSSR shall confirm that prior to putting into service, the construction and equipment being used is in accordance with design specifications. The PSSR also confirms that the safety,

operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and adequate training for each employee involved has been completed. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention measures are properly implemented. 



Mechanical Integrity

A mechanical integrity program has been developed as part of PSM that defines requirements for ensuring the integrity of process equipment.  The Facility has on site written procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, pumps, emergency shutdown systems and controls in a safe operating condition. These written procedures help ensure the safe implementation of maintenance activities thus promoting the reliability and integrity of process equipment.  This program also includes training, regular inspections and equipment testing. 



Management of Change

The Facility has a comprehensive Management of Change (MOC) program that reviews all proposed changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, procedures, materials and design conditions prior to implementation of the change.  Changes are reviewed by an interdisciplinary team to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by a process change. 





Incident Investigation

FHR has procedures to promptly investigate any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a release of a regulated substance, fire/explosion, major property damage, environmental damage, or personal injury.  The procedures establish the minimum guidelines and activities of the incident investigation program in order to reduce the likelihood of repetitive occurrences of events which could reasonably lead to catastrophic releases.  Investigations will be undertaken by a team to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to preve

nt a similar release in the future. Corrective actions are tracked until they are completed. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years. 



Compliance Audits

The Facility regularly conducts audits of the provisions of RMP and PSM to verify that procedures and practices developed under the standards are adequate and are being followed.  A compliance audit of each program is conducted every three years. The audits include a review of documentation and process safety information, inspection of the physical facilities, and interviews with all levels of plant personnel. The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Facility management for resolution. Findings and corrective actions taken in response to each finding are tracked until completion. 



4.      Five Year Accident History

In the five years preceding submittal of this plan, there were no accidental releases with on-site or off-site consequences meeting EPA criteria for inclusion in this plan.



5.    Emergency Response Program

FHR maintains an electronic Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP), which includes the Facility emergency response program, to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first-aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.   In addition, FHR has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to pe

rform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes or emergency response procedures. 



6.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety practices are continually reviewed. Equipment and maintenance programs are monitored on an ongoing basis.  At the submission of this plan, no immediate changes are scheduled.
